entity1.name: Sleep
entity1.description: A fundamental biological process essential for human health and well-being.

entity2.name: Human Health
entity2.description: The state of being free from illness or injury, which is supported by adequate sleep.

entity3.name: Well-Being
entity3.description: A state of being comfortable, healthy, and happy, which can be enhanced by sufficient sleep.

entity4.name: sleep
entity4.description: A naturally recurring state of rest characterized by altered consciousness, relatively inhibited sensory activity, and reduced muscle activity.

entity5.name: stages of sleep
entity5.description: The distinct phases that occur during the sleep cycle, typically divided into non-rapid eye movement (NREM) and rapid eye movement (REM) stages.

entity6.name: factors that influence sleep
entity6.description: Various internal and external elements that can affect the quality and quantity of sleep, such as age, health conditions, environment, and lifestyle choices.

entity7.name: adequate amount of rest
entity7.description: The sufficient duration and quality of sleep necessary to maintain physical and mental well-being.

entity8.name: sleep
entity8.description: A naturally recurring state characterized by reduced or absent consciousness, relatively suspended sensory activity, and inactivity of nearly all voluntary muscles.

entity9.name: stages
entity9.description: Distinct phases that occur during the sleep cycle, each characterized by specific brain wave patterns and physiological changes.

entity10.name: sleep cycle
entity10.description: The progression of sleep stages that occurs repeatedly throughout a period of sleep, typically lasting about 90 minutes in humans.

entity11.name: rapid eye movement (REM) sleep
entity11.description: A stage of sleep characterized by rapid movements of the eyes, increased respiration rate, and greater dreaming.

entity12.name: non-REM sleep
entity12.description: A stage of deep sleep that is divided into several stages, each with distinct brain wave patterns and physiological characteristics.

entity13.name: Non-REM sleep
entity13.description: A stage of sleep characterized by the absence of rapid eye movements, muscle atonia, and dreaming.

entity14.name: N1
entity14.description: The first stage of non-REM sleep, also known as light sleep, where the body begins to relax and slow down.

entity15.name: N2
entity15.description: The second stage of non-REM sleep, characterized by further slowing of brain waves and deeper relaxation.

entity16.name: N3
entity16.description: The third stage of non-REM sleep, also known as deep sleep or slow-wave sleep, where the body undergoes physical restoration.

entity17.name: N1 stage
entity17.description: The lightest stage of sleep where individuals may experience drifting in and out of consciousness.

entity18.name: N2 stage
entity18.description: A specific stage of non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep characterized by a decrease in body temperature and heart rate, as well as the onset of sleep spindles and K-complexes.

entity19.name: sleep spindles
entity19.description: Brief bursts of brain activity that occur during stage 2 (N2) of non-rapid eye movement sleep, typically lasting for about half a second to two seconds.

entity20.name: K-complexes
entity20.description: A high-amplitude delta wave that occurs during stage 2 (N2) of non-rapid eye movement sleep, often in response to external stimuli or internal events.

entity21.name: N3 stage
entity21.description: A stage of sleep characterized by slow brain waves, also known as slow-wave sleep.

entity22.name: slow-wave sleep
entity22.description: The deepest stage of non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep, associated with restorative processes in the body.

entity23.name: REM sleep
entity23.description: A stage of sleep characterized by rapid eye movement and increased brain activity, during which most dreaming occurs.

entity24.name: Rapid eye movements
entity24.description: A characteristic of certain sleep stages, particularly REM sleep, where the eyes move quickly in various directions.

entity25.name: Increased brain activity
entity25.description: Refers to heightened levels of neural activity in the brain, often observed during specific states such as REM sleep or under certain stimuli.

entity26.name: Muscle paralysis
entity26.description: A state where muscles are unable to move, commonly occurring during REM sleep to prevent the acting out of dreams.

entity27.name: REM sleep
entity27.description: A stage of sleep characterized by rapid eye movements, low muscle tone throughout the body, and vivid dreams.

entity28.name: memory consolidation
entity28.description: The process by which new information is encoded and stabilized in the brain for long-term storage.

entity29.name: emotional processing
entity29.description: The cognitive and physiological processes that occur when an individual perceives, interprets, and responds to emotional stimuli.

entity30.name: non-REM sleep
entity30.description: A stage of sleep characterized by the absence of rapid eye movements, relatively low brain activity, and muscle tone.

entity31.name: REM sleep
entity31.description: A stage of sleep marked by rapid eye movements, high brain activity, and vivid dreaming.

entity32.name: sleep
entity32.description: A naturally recurring state characterized by reduced or absent consciousness, relatively suspended sensory activity, and inactivity of nearly all voluntary muscles.

entity33.name: physiological processes
entity33.description: The functions and activities that occur within living organisms to maintain life, including but not limited to metabolism, homeostasis, and cell signaling.

entity34.name: neurotransmitters
entity34.description: Endogenous chemicals that transmit signals across a synapse from one neuron to another 'target' neuron or other cells, such as muscles or glands.

entity35.name: circadian rhythm
entity35.description: An internal biological process that regulates the sleep-wake cycle and repeats roughly every 24 hours.

entity36.name: body's internal clock
entity36.description: A metaphorical term for the circadian rhythm, which helps regulate various biological processes including sleep and wakefulness.

entity37.name: suprachiasmatic nucleus
entity37.description: A small region in the brain that acts as the body's master clock, regulating circadian rhythms.

entity38.name: brain
entity38.description: The central organ of the nervous system, responsible for controlling and coordinating bodily functions and activities.

entity39.name: melatonin
entity39.description: A hormone produced by the pineal gland that regulates sleep-wake cycles.

entity40.name: circadian rhythm
entity40.description: An internal process that regulates the sleep-wake cycle and repeats roughly every 24 hours.

entity41.name: adenosine
entity41.description: A chemical that promotes sleep by binding to receptors in the brain, leading to drowsiness.

entity42.name: serotonin
entity42.description: A neurotransmitter involved in regulating mood, appetite, and sleep.

entity43.name: dopamine
entity43.description: A neurotransmitter associated with pleasure, reward, and regulation of movement and emotional responses.

entity44.name: neurotransmitter systems
entity44.description: A group of nerve cells that communicate with each other using chemical messengers called neurotransmitters.

entity45.name: sleep disorders
entity45.description: A range of conditions characterized by disturbances in the amount, quality, or timing of sleep.

entity46.name: insomnia
entity46.description: A common sleep disorder where individuals have trouble falling asleep, staying asleep, or both.

entity47.name: narcolepsy
entity47.description: A chronic neurological disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden attacks of sleep.

entity48.name: sleep apnea
entity48.description: A potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep.

entity49.name: light exposure
entity49.description: The amount of light that a person is exposed to, which can affect various biological processes including sleep.

entity50.name: noise
entity50.description: Sound levels in the environment that can disturb or enhance sleep quality depending on their intensity and nature.

entity51.name: temperature
entity51.description: The degree of hotness or coldness in the sleeping environment, which can significantly affect comfort and sleep quality.

entity52.name: lifestyle choices
entity52.description: Personal habits and decisions that individuals make, such as diet, exercise, and bedtime routines, which can influence sleep patterns and quality.

entity53.name: melatonin
entity53.description: A hormone produced by the pineal gland that regulates sleep-wake cycles.

entity54.name: sleep-wake cycle
entity54.description: The natural pattern of sleeping and waking over a 24-hour period, also known as the circadian rhythm.

entity55.name: noise
entity55.description: A disturbance that can affect the quality of sleep.

entity56.name: temperature
entity56.description: The degree of hotness or coldness in an environment, which can impact sleep quality.

entity57.name: sleep
entity57.description: A naturally recurring state characterized by reduced consciousness and metabolic activity.

entity58.name: Sleep
entity58.description: A naturally recurring state characterized by reduced or absent consciousness, relatively suspended sensory activity, and inactivity of nearly all voluntary muscles.

entity59.name: immune function
entity59.description: The body's ability to defend against pathogens and other foreign substances through the immune system.

entity60.name: metabolism
entity60.description: The set of life-sustaining chemical reactions in organisms, including anabolism (building molecules) and catabolism (breaking down molecules).

entity61.name: cognitive function
entity61.description: The mental processes involved in acquiring knowledge and understanding through thought, experience, and the senses.

entity62.name: Chronic sleep deprivation
entity62.description: A prolonged lack of adequate sleep that can lead to various health issues.

entity63.name: obesity
entity63.description: A medical condition characterized by excessive body fat accumulation, which may adversely affect health.

entity64.name: diabetes
entity64.description: A group of metabolic disorders characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period.

entity65.name: cardiovascular disease
entity65.description: A class of diseases that involve the heart or blood vessels, including conditions such as coronary artery disease and hypertension.

entity66.name: mental health disorders
entity66.description: A range of conditions affecting a person's thinking, feeling, or mood, which may be characterized by significant impairment in daily functioning.

entity67.name: sleep
entity67.description: A naturally recurring state characterized by reduced or absent consciousness, relatively suspended sensory activity, and inactivity of nearly all voluntary muscles.

entity68.name: human health
entity68.description: The condition of being free from illness or injury; a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being.

entity69.name: well-being
entity69.description: A state of being comfortable, healthy, or happy.

entity70.name: sleep
entity70.description: A naturally recurring state characterized by reduced or absent consciousness, relatively suspended sensory activity, and inactivity of nearly all voluntary muscles.

entity71.name: stages of sleep
entity71.description: Distinct phases that occur during the sleep cycle, each characterized by specific brain wave activity and physiological changes.
